thread.title: EU Referendum result: North East Leave campaigners celebrate a 'tremendous day'
thread.title_full: EU Referendum result: North East Leave campaigners celebrate a 'tremendous day'

author: Dan O'Donoghue
title: EU Referendum result: North East Leave campaigners celebrate a 'tremendous day'
text:
The North East - and the UK - turned its back on the EU, with Newcastle the region's only authority to favour a Remain vote Shares Get daily news by email The Northumberland count at Blyth Sports Centre 
Leave campaigners hailed a “tremendous day for Britain” as the North East - and UK - snubbed the EU in a historic referendum. 
The fuse was lit in Sunderland at around 12.15am on Friday and Brexit fireworks flew from Northumberland to Teesside. 
In all, 1.34 million of us turned out to vote across the region - with 778,103 siding with leave and 562,595 with remain, meaning a resounding 58% voted for Brexit. 
Every North East authority beside Newcastle - which only marginally voted remain - bolted for the exit door. 
As night melted into early morning, the results for Leave continued to file in; South Tyneside with 62%, Hartlepool with 69%, Middlesbrough with 65%, Stockton-on-Tees with 61%, Redcar with 66%, North Tyneside with 53%, Darlington with 56%, Gateshead with 56%, Durham with 57% and Northumberland with 54%. 
The ecstasy in the Leave camp could barely be contained and in Sunderland campaigners hoisted their comrades up on shoulders and cheers drowned out the counting officer announcing the result. 
Similar scenes were witnessed at counts across the North East as Nigel Farage’s early admission that Leave had lost evaporated. 
Judith Wallace, North Tyneside Leave campaigner and the borough’s Conservative party leader, said: “I’m absolutely thrilled. People realised that the essence of this argument was the democratic one - whether we are going to be a self-governing democratic country again or whether we are going to be governed by unelected officials in Europe.” Jonathan Arnott MEP 
North East UKIP MEP Jonathan Arnott said: “This is a tremendous day for Britain and for our democratic process. 
“The people of the North East have led the way in voting clearly for Brexit. The British people as a whole have spoken and we have regained control over our own destiny. 
“Now the hard work begins: we must now deal with our European colleagues as friends and neighbours and negotiate a deal for the future which allows us to trade freely with the EU, control our borders and work together for our mutual benefit.” 
The mood on the side of Remain was fatigued as the realisation hit - the region and indeed the nation had turned its back on the EU. North-East Labour MEP Jude Kirton-Darling 
Jude Kirton-Darling, Labour MEP for the North East, said: “It is with great disappointment and sadness that I have learned that the United Kingdom has voted to leave the European Union. 
“There’s been lots of anger on the doorstep about the future direction of this country and people are rightly concerned about housing, precarious work and the state of our public services. People must be listened to and I hope the Government listens now.” 
Paul Brannen, another North East Labour MEP, added: “This is not the result the Labour Party and the main trade unions were hoping for. 
“We strongly believed that our place is within the Europe Union, working together with our neighbours for peace and prosperity. 
“I hope that those who negotiate our exit from the EU don’t forget the people of the North East but frankly I can’t see a bunch of Tories in London doing that. 
“However I will continue to work hard for the region as we now face a difficult and uncertain future but we are a resilient region and together we will pull through.” More on the EU Referendum
